description: From Middle English juge, jugge, borrowed from Old French juge, from Latin iūdex. Displaced native Old English dēma.

entries.meaning: A public official whose duty it is to administer the law, especially by presiding over trials and rendering judgments; a justice.
A person who decides the fate of someone or something that has been called into question.
A person officiating at a sports event, a contest, or similar.
examples: At a boxing match, the decision of the judges is final.

entries.meaning: A person who evaluates something or forms an opinion.
examples: She is a good judge of wine.
They say he is a poor judge of character considering all the unreliable friends he has made.

entries.meaning: (historical, biblical) A shophet, a temporary leader appointed in times of crisis in ancient Israel.

description: From Middle English jugen, borrowed from Anglo-Norman juger, from Old French jugier, from Latin iūdicāre.

verbs.description: judge (third-person singular simple present judges, present participle judging, simple past and past participle judged)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To sit in judgment on; to pass sentence on (a person or matter).
examples: A higher power will judge you after you are dead.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To sit in judgment, to act as judge.
examples: Justices in this country judge without appeal.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To sentence to punishment, to judicially condemn.
examples: He was judged to die for his crimes.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To award judicially; to adjudge.
(transitive) To form an opinion on; to appraise.
examples: I judge a man’s character by the cut of his suit.

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To constitute a fitting appraisal or criterion of; to provide a basis for forming an opinion on.
(intransitive) To arbitrate; to pass opinion on something, especially to settle a dispute etc.
examples: We cannot both be right: you must judge between us.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To have as an opinion; to consider, suppose.
examples: I judge it safe to leave the house once again.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To form an opinion; to infer.
examples: I judge from the sky that it might rain later.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To criticize or label another person or thing.
examples: There's something wrong with the world today; the light bulb's getting dim.
If you can judge a wise man by the color of his skin,
Mister, you're a better man than I

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To govern as biblical judge or shophet (over some jurisdiction).
